title: 106_s2477
content: The Act is titled the "Social Security Beneficiaries Protection Act" and authorizes the reissuance of benefits misused by organizational representative payees. The "Social Security Beneficiaries Protection Act" authorizes reissuance of misused benefits by organizational representative payees under OASDI and SSI. The "Social Security Beneficiaries Protection Act" allows the Commissioner of Social Security to reimburse beneficiaries or their alternative payees for misused benefits by organizational representative payees, effective for cases determined after the Act's enactment. The "Social Security Beneficiaries Protection Act" allows reimbursement for misused benefits by organizational representative payees through bonding and licensing requirements. The "Social Security Beneficiaries Protection Act" requires representative payees to provide a bond meeting specified requirements and be licensed in each state they serve. The amendments take effect on the first day of the thirteenth month after enactment. The amendments take effect on the first day of the thirteenth month after enactment. Fee forfeiture for benefit misuse by qualified organizational representative payees. Amendments to the Social Security Act and SSI Act now prohibit qualified organizations from collecting fees if they misuse an individual's benefits. Any fees collected in such cases will be considered as part of the individual's misused benefits. Any fees collected in such cases will be considered as part of the individual's misused benefits. The amendments also specify that a qualified organization cannot charge a fee if the Commissioner of Social Security or a court determines benefit misuse, with any collected amount treated as misused benefits. These changes apply to cases where benefit misuse is determined after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 5. Liability of nongovernmental representative payees for misused benefits. Liability of nongovernmental representative payees for misused benefits: Amends the Social Security Act to hold representative payees accountable for misusing an individual's benefits, treating the misused amount as an overpayment to the payee. The Commissioner will certify recovered amounts to individuals or their representative payees, not exceeding the total benefit amount misused. Amendments to the Social Security Act hold non-governmental payees liable for misusing benefits. The representative payee is liable for misused benefits and must repay the amount. The Commissioner will recover the misused amount and make payment to the individual or their alternative representative payee. The total amount paid to the individual or their alternative representative payee should not exceed the total benefit amount misused. Amendments to the Social Security Act hold non-governmental payees accountable for misusing benefits. The amendments made by this section apply to benefit misuse by a representative payee determined after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 6. EXTENSION OF THE CIVIL MONETARY PENALTY AUTHORITY. Section 1129(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to include provisions regarding the misuse of payments received as a representative payee. Section 1129 of the Social Security Act is amended to impose civil money penalties for violations related to the misuse of payments by a representative payee. Amendments are made to various sections of the Act to address fraud, false statements, and misrepresentations. The effective date of these amendments is specified. The amendments made by this section will be effective for violations committed after the enactment of this Act.
